author: Carlton D. White cwhite@mdjonline.com (noreply@mdjonline.com)
title: Whitefield's Madison Barnett qualifies for USGA tournament
text: slideshow Madison Barnett watched last year’s U.S. Women’s Amateur Four-Ball Championship on TV last May and thought it might be fun to play in a championship event like that.“I thought it would be cool to do, but I didn’t really know any of the dates or when or where anything took place to get involved,” the Whitefield Academy senior said. “I thought it would be cool to be in it, but I didn’t really go beyond that initial feeling.”Fortunately, one of her friends did, and now Barnett and playing partner Amanda Doherty will play in the USGA event next May after winning an 18-hole qualifier Wednesday at The Oaks Course in Covington.Barnett, who has committed to play golf at Wofford, teamed with Doherty, a senior at the Galloway School who is committed to Florida State, to shoot a 4-under par 67 in the qualifier, beating out seven other teams for the opportunity to participate in next May’s U.S. Women’s Amateur Four-Ball at Streamsong Resort in Florida.“Me and Amanda have been friends since we were 4, and she asked me about playing in the qualifier, so we signed up,” Barnett said. “It was fun playing with her. We had great weather at the course and just had a lot of fun out there.”Four-ball golf involves two two-person teams playing against one another, where each teammate plays their own ball. Each hole is scored using the lower score between the two teammates.Playing against Dalton’s Carson Roberts and Chatsworth’s Savannah Satterfield, Barnett eagled the first hole and Doherty birdied No. 2 to put them at 3-under early. The duo parred holes Nos. 3-14 until Doherty birdied 15 to move her and Barnett to 4-under. They parred the 16th and bogeyed 17 before Barnett birdied 18 to secure the victory.“I hit a pitching wedge off the fairway from 106 yards away into the first hole for an eagle on the par-4,” Barnett said. “After we bogeyed the 17th, I made a 15-foot putt for birdie on the par-4 18th, which helped us win the tournament.“It will be exciting and fun to be in a national event. It was just great for Amanda and me to be able to come together and play so well. Hopefully, we’ll be able to do it again in May.”Barnett and Doherty beat Charlotte Daughan of Orlando, Florida, and Mercedes Huarte of Argentina, who shot 68.“Just from being friends, there was a lot of trust between us,” Barnett said. “We had a lot of good shots, and we played well. We just had each other’s backs and didn’t focus on anyone else — just ourselves. When we saw our score compared to everyone else’s, we just couldn’t believe we did it.”The U.S. Women’s Four-Ball made its debut in May, essentially replacing the U.S. Women’s Amateur Public Links Championship. Roswell’s Rinko Mitsunaga, now a freshman at Georgia, won the inaugural event with teammate Mika Liu. Share This Article | similar stories
